title: "Disclose Electoral Bonds' Details By Tomorrow": Top Court Rejects SBI Plea
comments: The Supreme Court on Monday, March 11, dismissed the plea filed by the State Bank of India (SBI) seeking an extension till June 30 for disclosure of the data on electoral bonds. The five-judge bench headed by Chief Justice of India DY Chandrachud directed the  SBI to disclose details by the end of business hours on March 12, Tuesday. The Election Commission of India (ECI) shall publish the information on its website by 5 pm on March 15. The court directed the bank to comply with the prescribed timeline.

– In the original judgement of February 15, the court had directed for disclosure of –
1. Details of bonds purchased (date, name, denominations)
2. Details of bonds redeemed by political parties (date of encashment, denominations)

The SBI claimed that these two details are readily available but in two separate silos.

In today’s order, the court has directed the SBI to disclose details of these two silos. There is no direction for SBI to match the two silos, and determine which company contributed how much to which party. After the disclosure, we are likely to have two lists – donors and parties – with no corelation.

SBI application seeking extension till June 30 is dismissed.

– The SBI has submitted that donor KYC, details of political parties are in two different silos.

– The SBI has submitted that if two silos of info need to be shared, it can share details within 2-3 weeks.

– The SBI has submitted that if donor details need to be matched with political parties, bank would require time till June 30.

– Electoral bonds scheme stipulated that info furnished by buyer of bond shall be treated as confidential, and shall be disclosed only by orders of a court, law enforcement agencies.

– The SBI is mandated to disclose info when demanded by a court.
